s: ^Hi Mr. Calindas! I'm doing well, how are you?.
^So far, so good! How are things with you?

Chat1: ^Mrcalindas?Smiling "I'm doing well. I'm looking forward to trivia night at the Community Center this week."
^Mrcalindas?Smiling "What brings you to the clinic today?"

s: ^Wow, one win and you become single-minded!

Chat2: ^Mrcalindas?Smiling "I'm not going to apologize that I've found a new joy in life! I will admit that I was a shocked as everyone else when I won."
^Mrcalindas?Smiling "I want to defend my title at least once. I promise not to get a big head, though!"

s: ^If your head were as big as all the useful info it holds, you'd never get through a door. Let yourself savor it.
^I was just messing with you! I'm actually here to try and learn more about diabetes.

Chat3: ^Mrcalindas?Smiling "You made a good showing, my friend. and don't discount the things you know; you're quite a resource for our community."

s: ^Thanks! Speaking of which, I was wondering if I could ask you some questions about diabetes?
^I appreciate it. I'm actually here for my friend, though - they have a parent recently diagnosed with diabetes.

Explain1: ^Mrcalindas?Neutral "Diabetes is a long-term health condition that requires ongoing monitoring. Outcomes can be quite good, and managing the condition can be quite successful with the right tools."
^Mrcalindas?Neutral "I am guessing that we are discussing Type 2 diabetes - which is sometimes referred to as "adult onset diabetes"."
^Mrcalindas?Neutral "As we age, sometimes our bodies produce less insulin than we need. Or they become less effective at using the insulin we do create."

s: ^Sort of. Can you tell me more?
^Yes! But what are the next steps after diagnosis?

Explain2: ^Mrcalindas?Neutral "Insulin is created by an organ called the pancreas. Much of the food we eat is broken down into sugars, which our body use as fuel. Insulin is like a key that allows our cells to use that fuel."

^Mrcalindas?Neutral "If there isn't enough insulin, or your body doesn't know what to do with the insulin that is created, too much blood sugar stays in your blood stream, where it can cause havoc over the long-term."

s: ^Is it difficult to treat? What are the next steps?

Suggestion1: ^Mrcalindas_Day 1_Healthy Diet and Exercise can help manage diabete_Elisa1-1

Suggestion1.#: notification Mrcalindas_Day 1_Healthy Diet and Exercise can help manage diabete_Elisa1-1

Suggestion1: ^Mrcalindas?Smiling "The biggest things to focus on are a diverse, nutrient-rich diet and regular exercise."
^Mrcalindas?Smiling "We have specialists at the clinic who help people learn about basics like portion control, what a 'balanced diet' looks like, and so on.
^Mrcalindas?Smiling "To summarize, though, eat small portions, make sure you do some light activity every day, and do more moderate activity a few times a week."

s: ^But how do you know if your blood sugar is getting better or not?

Suggestion2: ^Mrcalindas_Day 1_Work with your doctor to create a plan that combines diet, exercise, monitoring, and medicine to control your blood sugar and manage your diabetes_Elisa1-2

Suggestion2.#: notification Mrcalindas_Day 1_Work with your doctor to create a plan that combines diet, exercise, monitoring, and medicine to control your blood sugar and manage your diabetes_Elisa1-2

Suggestion2: ^Mrcalindas?Smiling "Well, it's fairly simple. Other than looking after your diet and exercising regularly, you'd be monitoring your blood sugar levels at home via a blood glucose meter."
^Mrcalindas?Smiling "How often you have to monitor those levels varies from person-to-person, but it's usually once a day."
^Mrcalindas?Smiling "Otherwise, treatment can include oral medications or insulin therapy via injections."
^Mrcalindas?Smiling "Find a doctor - an endocrinologist - you feel comfortable with. They will be your partner in navigating those choices."

s: ^This has been really helpful, thank you Mr. Calindas!
